snippet: Although a grand jury decided not to indict a police officer who shot a 68-year-old man in his apartment, federal prosecutors will see if the victim’s rights were violated.
abstract: Federal prosecutors will begin review of whether civil rights laws were violated in case of Kenneth Chamberlain Sr, who was shot to death in 2011 by Police Officer Anthony Carelli in his White Plains, NY, apartment; police, responding to a call for medical help that Chamberlain had unknowingly triggered, contend that he met their attempts to enter his home with violent resistance. (M)
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan will begin a review of whether civil rights laws were violated in the case of a 68-year-old man who was shot to death last year by a police officer in his apartment in White Plains, N.Y., a spokeswoman for the United States attorney in Manhattan said on Friday. The spokeswoman, Ellen Davis, said prosecutors would examine ''all of the available evidence'' about the death of Kenneth Chamberlain Sr., a former Westchester County correction officer and Marine.

headline.main: Case of Man Killed by Police Is to Get Civil Rights Review
